Abstract Abstract
DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting, and DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting, and
Conformance) is a scalable mechanism by which a mail-originating Conformance) is a scalable mechanism by which a mail-originating
organization can express domain-level policies and preferences for organization can express domain-level policies and preferences for

1. Introduction 1. Introduction
DMARC [RFC7489] provides email sending organizational policy DMARC [RFC7489] provides email sending organizational policy
information to email receivers. Due to the design of DMARC [RFC7489] information to email receivers. Due to the design of DMARC [RFC7489]
and the nature of the Internet email architecture [RFC5598], there and the nature of the Internet email architecture [RFC5598], there
are interoperability issues associated with DMARC [RFC7489] are interoperability issues associated with DMARC [RFC7489]
deployment. These are discused in Interoperability Issues between deployment. These are discussed in Interoperability Issues between
DMARC and Indirect Email Flows [RFC7960]. These issues are not DMARC and Indirect Email Flows [RFC7960]. These issues are not
applicable to TLDs, since they do not send mail. applicable to TLDs, since they do not send mail.
DMARC [RFC7489], by design, does not support requirements of TLD DMARC [RFC7489], by design, does not support requirements of TLD
operators. For TLDs that require use of DMARC [RFC7489], a subset of operators. For TLDs that require use of DMARC [RFC7489], a subset of

2.2. Top Level Domain (TLD) 2.2. Top Level Domain (TLD)
The global Internet Domain Name System (DNS) is documented in The global Internet Domain Name System (DNS) is documented in
numerous Requests for Comment (RFC). It defines a tree of names numerous Requests for Comment (RFC). It defines a tree of names
starting with root, ".", immediately below which are Top Level Domain starting with root, ".", immediately below which are Top Level Domain
names such as ".com" and ".us". The usage for TLD DMARC is broader names such as ".com" and ".us". The usage for TLD DMARC is broader
and includes all domains above the organizational level in the tree, and includes all domains above the organizational level in the tree,
e.g. ".gov.uk". e.g., ".gov.uk".
2.3. TLD Operator (TLDO) 2.3. TLD Operator (TLDO)
A TLD Operator manages operations within their TLD. A TLD Operator manages operations within their TLD.
2.4. TLDO Controlled Domain Names 2.4. TLDO Controlled Domain Names
TLDO Controlled Domain Names are names in the DNS that are managed by TLDO Controlled Domain Names are names in the DNS that are managed by
TLDOs and not available for use as organizational domains (the term a TLDO and not available for use as Organizational Domains (the term
organizational domains is defined in DMARC [RFC7489]). Depending on organizational domains is defined in DMARC [RFC7489]). Depending on
TLD policy, these will have one (e.g. ".com") or more (e.g. ".co.uk") TLD policy, these will have one (e.g., ".com") or more (e.g.,
name components. ".co.uk") name components.
2.5. Non-existent Domains 2.5. Non-existent Domains
For DMARC [RFC7489] purposes, a non-existent domain is a domain name For DMARC [RFC7489] purposes, a non-existent domain is a domain name
that publishes none of A, AAAA, or MX records. This is a broader that publishes none of A, AAAA, or MX records. This is a broader
definition than that in NXDOMAIN [RFC8020]. definition than that in NXDOMAIN [RFC8020].

4.1. Feedback leakage 4.1. Feedback leakage
Providing feedback reporting to TLDOs can, in some cases create Providing feedback reporting to TLDOs can, in some cases, create
leakage of information outside of an organization to the TLDO. There leakage of information outside of an organization to the TLDO. There
are roughly three cases to consider: are roughly three cases to consider:
o Branded TLDs (e.g. ".google"), RUA and RUF reports based on TLD o Branded TLDs (e.g., ".google"), RUA and RUF reports based on TLD
DMARC have the potential to contain information about emails DMARC have the potential to contain information about emails
related to entities managed by the organization, but since both related to entities managed by the organization. Since both the
the TLDO and the organizational domain owners are common, there is TLDO and the Organizational Domain owners are common, there is no
no privacy risk for either normal or nxdomain reporting. privacy risk for either normal or Non-existent Domain reporting.
o Multi-organization TLDs that require DMARC usage (e.g. ".bank": o Multi-organization TLDs that require DMARC usage (e.g., ".bank"):
TLD DMARC based reports will only be generated for domains that do TLD DMARC based reports will only be generated for domains that do
not publish DMARC policy at the organizational level. For domains not publish a DMARC policy at the organizational level. For
that do publish the required DMARC policy records, the feedback domains that do publish the required DMARC policy records, the
reporting addresses (RUA and RUF) of the organization will be feedback reporting addresses (RUA and RUF) of the organization
used. Since TLD DMARC is limited to TLDs that mandate will be used. Since TLD DMARC is limited to TLDs that mandate
organizational domains publish DMARC policy, the risk of this organizational domains publish DMARC policy for existing domains,
issue is limited to organizational domains that are out of the risk of this issue is limited to organizational domains that
compliance with TLD policy. are out of compliance with TLD policy.
o Multi-organization TLDs (e.g. ".com") that do not mandate DMARC o Multi-organization TLDs (e.g., ".com") that do not mandate DMARC
usage. Privacy risks for organizational domains within such TLDs usage. Privacy risks for organizational domains within such TLDs
would be significant. This is mitigated by the limitation of TLD would be significant. This is mitigated by the limitation to only
DMARC to exclude such TLDs and the requirement for a public IANA include TLDs listed in the public IANA DMARC TLD Registry
registry that is required to exclude such TLDs. described in Section 6.1.
TLDOs will receive feedback on non-existant domains, which may be TLDOs will receive feedback on non-existant domains, which may be
similar to existing organizational domains. Feedback related to such similar to existing organizational domains. Feedback related to such
cousin domains have a small risk of carrying information related to cousin domains have a small risk of carrying information related to
an actual organizational domain. To minimize this potential concern, an actual organizational domain. To minimize this potential concern,
TLD DMARC feedback is best limited to Aggregate Reports. Feedback TLD DMARC feedback is best limited to Aggregate Reports. Feedback
